Dear ___,

This letter summarizes your recent hospital stay, which began on March 10, 2024, and pertains to your anticipated discharge on March 20, 2024. You were admitted following a fall accompanied by a subsequent loss of consciousness.

During your hospital stay, you underwent a comprehensive assessment, including a CT scan conducted on March 11, 2024. The imaging confirmed the presence of a hemorrhagic stroke in the right hemisphere of your brain, leading to an unspecified intracerebral hemorrhage diagnosis.

Throughout your hospitalization, we monitored your condition closely, beginning with the results from your initial examination. You presented with decreased consciousness, slurred speech, and a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 11. The laboratory results from March 11, 2024, indicated a slightly low hemoglobin level and elevated white blood cell count. Furthermore, your coagulation profile showed an increased International Normalized Ratio (INR), suggesting a prolonged bleeding time.

To manage your condition, you were prescribed Mannitol at a dose of 0.25 g/kg every 6 hours to address cerebral edema. Additionally, antihypertensive medications were administered to manage your blood pressure, with dosages adjusted as needed to achieve optimal control.

Despite our interventions, your neurological status showed limited improvement during your stay. Ward rounds recorded persistent issues, including right-sided weakness and ongoing slurred speech. Safety measures were enacted to prevent additional falls due to observed agitation and confusion. As of March 12, it was necessary to discuss your prognosis and continued care needs with your family, stressing that discharge was not yet deemed safe. Your condition remained critical and required diligent monitoring.

As you prepare for your expected discharge, we have discussed the ongoing care you will need at home. It is crucial to continue monitoring your symptoms and attend follow-up appointments to assess your recovery and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan.

If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to reach out to your healthcare team. We are committed to supporting your recovery and ensuring you receive the best care possible.

Wishing you a safe and steady recovery,
